comments:
This class covers an introduction to non-linear dynamics, chaos, bifurcation, and
qualitative analysis of continuous and discrete dynamical systems and their use in
understanding complex behavior of systems. Emphasis is placed on understanding
qualitative features of models of electrical, mechanical, and biological systems.
This course was an awesome course in the opinion of many students; some even
found it the best class they had taken at Penn: "The best course I've had in the ESE
department." Students found that they learned much information in class that was actually
very applicable. You learn how to solve problems in different ways. Information can be
dry, but the professor makes lectures interesting.
Professor Ghirst was highly liked by his students. "I heard wonderful things about
Ghrist, the professor, which is why I decided to take this course” said one student. “Those
ratings were true to fact and made this the most pleasant engineering course that I've
taken at Penn." Another student said: "Dr. Ghrist clearly communicates the core content.
He understands the truly amazing implications of some of the ideas in the course and
doesn't fail to highlight their wonderful applications and philosophical issues relating to
them." Dr. Ghrist's lectures were exciting and engaging and actively taught students.
Problem sets were bi-weekly and there was one midterm, and were thought to be
challenging. There were more computer projects than exams, which seemed refreshing to
some students. In addition, the students felt that the professor did not put much emphasis
on homework, which made things less stressful. Overall, this course is enjoyable and
highly recommended. Prerequisites for this class are MATH240 and PHYS150.
Students in the past recommended taking MATH240, MATH312, and ESE210.
